{"post_stream":{"posts":[{"id":3275483,"name":"Elena Wu","username":"oboesandclarinets","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/oboesandclarinets/{size}/187351_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-07T16:27:16.476Z","cooked":"

My team has been considering shooting into the amp in addition to the speaker. We are wondering whether it is worth it to accomplish this, according to our CAD models a 75 degree or above angle will suffice but then we will have to make an angle changing mechanism to accommodate the speaker.

","post_number":1,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-01-07T16:27:16.476Z","reply_count":0,"reply_to_post_number":null,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":317,"reads":1605,"readers_count":1604,"score":1951.0,"yours":false,"topic_id":448187,"topic_slug":"shooting-into-the-amp","display_username":"Elena Wu","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":3}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":57711,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"Mechanical lead - 5422"},"post_url":"/t/shooting-into-the-amp/448187/1","custom_user_title":"Mechanical lead - 5422","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":3}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":3,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null,"can_vote":false},{"id":3275503,"name":"Eric Bergquist","username":"kitare102","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/kitare102/{size}/212327_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-07T16:46:39.952Z","cooked":"

The tricky part will be the fact that the amp is a shallow goal with little room for error. If you shoot a note in there and it doesn’t have very consistent dynamic behavior, you’ll bounce out a lot. That’s not to say a shooter for amp isn’t possible, but the critical part for anyone attempting it is prototyping and practice. Prototyping to make sure you can feasibly build a shooter with enough control to reliably interact with the amp, and practice to assess the final variability of the mechanism so that you can be confident you’ll make the shot greater than X% of the time. This will require building an accurate mockup of the amp, preferably with the real materials to make sure interactions are consistent with the official field.

The notes are 2" thick. The amp is 3" deep. Shooting into the amp is going to be VERY difficult.

Cranberry alarm is testing this on stream right now with their shooter that’s pretty similar to the kitbot.

YouTube

Robot in 3 Days | Cranberry Alarm | Sunday Stream | Ri3D

Sunday Stream of Robot in 3 Days (Ri3D) with Cranberry Alarm from Indiana. Ask questions in chat!Stream Schedule (all times US Eastern UTC-05:00)9:00am Strea...

Edit: if you go back around 20-30 minutes they were testing a pasta roller intake on the amp shooting it downwards and that worked really well.

While we were messing around with the note yesterday, we discovered if you throw it really fast and hard at the wall, the note will press up flat against the wall and fall straight down quite reliably. Whether or not you can actually make a mechanism that can shoot the note at the speed and force required to do so is another question entirely, but it could be a promising approach if somebody manages to do that. Something to note, however, is that we only tested this by throwing it at a painted cinder block wall, so the actual interaction the note will have with the amp when shot from a robot could very well be different

Love this, kind of ridiculous it works!! Have you done more than one trial to test the consistency and if so what were the results?

","post_number":11,"post_type":1,"posts_count":52,"updated_at":"2024-01-08T00:33:33.533Z","reply_count":1,"reply_to_post_number":10,"quote_count":0,"incoming_link_count":10,"reads":971,"readers_count":970,"score":264.2,"yours":false,"topic_id":448187,"topic_slug":"shooting-into-the-amp","display_username":"Chase Vendrillo","primary_group_name":null,"flair_name":null,"flair_url":null,"flair_bg_color":null,"flair_color":null,"flair_group_id":null,"badges_granted":[],"version":1,"can_edit":false,"can_delete":false,"can_recover":false,"can_see_hidden_post":true,"can_wiki":false,"read":true,"user_title":"","reply_to_user":{"id":7146,"username":"wilsonmw04","name":"wilsonmw04","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wilsonmw04/{size}/141839_2.png"},"bookmarked":false,"actions_summary":[{"id":2,"count":1}],"moderator":false,"admin":false,"staff":false,"user_id":58319,"hidden":false,"trust_level":2,"deleted_at":null,"user_deleted":false,"edit_reason":null,"can_view_edit_history":true,"wiki":false,"user_custom_fields":{"user_field_4":"1699 Captain"},"post_url":"/t/shooting-into-the-amp/448187/11","custom_user_title":"1699 Captain","reactions":[{"id":"heart","type":"emoji","count":1}],"current_user_reaction":null,"reaction_users_count":1,"current_user_used_main_reaction":false,"can_accept_answer":false,"can_unaccept_answer":false,"accepted_answer":false,"topic_accepted_answer":null},{"id":3276102,"name":"wilsonmw04","username":"wilsonmw04","avatar_template":"/user_avatar/www.chiefdelphi.com/wilsonmw04/{size}/141839_2.png","created_at":"2024-01-08T01:02:37.686Z","cooked":"

wasn’t there today, but the team was doing a shotgun approach to Prototypes today. They said they did it between 5-10 times and was “consistent.” We will have more data Tuesday.

They also said the angle was right around 45 degrees.

Shooting into the amp in a similar way to the speaker is gonna be very difficult. It may be possible to use the same shooting mechanism just angled down towards the inside of the amp to score that way.
